text: Hi there. I'm in the Rio District. So I have emailed every single one of you a document with compiled research on the effects of masking on school-aged students. I received no response. I realize that the school board is impacted by a top-down effect for COVID protocols, but there are things that are within your control, and you have chosen to shirk your responsibilities to read, understand, and use data and statistics to drive decision-making for our children. Remember that ACPS teaches statistics to our kids.  As a pediatric speech-language pathologist, the research on the harmful impact of masking is daunting. But before I get to that, I want to share that children have a .000005 chance of dying from COVID. How does this stack up against children killed in car accidents? They are 11.5 times more likely to die in a car accident than from COVID. 11.5. A risk-reward calculation should and must be used when making decisions that impact our children. Back to masks. The great news about the kinds of masks our kids wear to school  is that they're 10 to 12% effective, according to a recent study at the University of Waterloo.  Said differently, masks are 88 to 90% ineffective. Why does that matter? Because as the paper I emailed all of you delineates, masking impacts the social-emotional development of at-risk children, literacy and phonological development of early readers, speech-language development and self-advocacy for children with special needs, and a significantly decreased acoustic environment for all in a classroom. While some of you are at a local gym working out within six feet of your trainer unmasked, you know who you are,  Our children are trying, trying their best to breathe, read lips and facial expressions, learn phonemes and hear clearly while an unbreathable barrier with 10 to 12% efficacy is strewn across our children's faces. On a related note, as a former scholastic and collegiate athlete and former varsity coach at an ACPS high school,  I find it appalling that you would be requiring vaccinations for student athletes as yet another power grab and mass shaming incident. These athletes who drive themselves to practices and contests are 11 and a half times more likely to kill themselves getting there than they are of ever dying from COVID, yet you're giving them an ultimatum. If you want to play the sport you love, you must sacrifice your own bodily autonomy to us, even though the risk of you dying from this thing is so nil. It's time for some perspective. Thank you.

text: I'm in the Ravana district. I oppose the policy requiring all student athletes to receive the vaccine or be subjected to weekly testing. The recent CDC update shows the vaccine is not as effective with the Delta variant as it was with the Alpha variant. This is evident as we see vaccinated staff members continue to get infected. If the goal is to prevent the spread of the disease, then all should be tested instead of just singling out a small minority.  This is clearly not equitable and creates barriers. The children of parents that have the flexibility or means to take them to get tested will be able to play sports. Those without will not. It is in direct contradiction to ACPS's value statement of, we will mitigate barriers and provide opportunities for every student to be academically successful. We know that playing sports allows students to do better academically.  Proposing to test these athletes during the school day singles them out amongst their peers and teachers. Kids notice everything. It risks violating their medical privacy and FERPA. It seems the purpose of this policy is to make things more difficult for families that have chosen not to vaccinate their athletes. Healthy, active teens are in the lowest risk category. Regarding quarantining policies, I wholeheartedly support quarantine measures if they are indeed preventing the spread. Unvaccinated students are required to quarantine if exposed.  Since the vaccine shows decreased efficacy against the Delta variant, should we not be quarantining everyone considered a close contact? Considering the interruption to education and the burden to families that quarantining causes, is ACPS collecting data to determine if it is effective? Does the data show that the students who are quarantined are subsequently testing positive? What is the threshold for determining if quarantining is worth the negative impact it is causing students and families?  For the sake of transparency, will the board please share that information with the community? Thank you.

text: OK, so you hear me? Yep. OK.  Thank you, members of the school board for your time and attention. People often reduce issues like whether vaccine mandates are moral to scientific questions. Science does give us valuable facts like at the FDA hearing on whether to approve boosters for all. A scientist reported the rate of vaccine induced myocarditis in 16 and 17 year old boys  to what has one in 317 science also tells us valuable information about coven risk, like it is highly dependent on age, and secondarily obesity, even though sometimes young and healthy people die for children the flu is more dangerous than coven even though children to can die.  But science only gives us information about the questions that are asked. For example, the CDC told us that teens are more likely to be hospitalized from COVID than from vaccine-induced myocarditis, but there have been no published studies directly comparing teen hospitalizations from COVID to teen hospitalizations from all vaccine side effects or the extent to which either category of hospitalization depends on obesity or other health factors.  Science gives population-level risk factors, sometimes broken into demographic groups and often not. For each of us as individuals though, of course, it cannot tell us whether risks of the vaccine outweigh the risks of COVID. Given that all pharmaceutical interventions involve risk, we have to ask, who is best suited to evaluate the individual factors that go into a cost-benefit analysis that may involve serious injury or death?  It is clear to me that values, not science are required to answer this question. We've heard a lot of messaging that the benefit is worth the risk, but the benefit to whom compared to the risk to whom, given the difference between demographic groups and risk.  For both the vaccine and the virus, it is clear that mandates, in fact, sacrifice the health of some for others. What I ask from each of you is that you take the time to sincerely listen inside yourself to your heart's deepest wisdom or to pray if you pray for guidance on this matter. speaker: grahampaige

text: Good evening, board members. I'm Pat McLaughlin, chief of strategic planning for the school division. And I'm here tonight to provide a COVID-19 status update, as well as an update on our staff vaccination program. And with me tonight is Eileen Gomez, our school nurse coordinator and our COVID coordinator who can provide some insights into any questions you may have. And also joining us tonight is Ryan McKay from the Blue Ridge Health Department, who can also give us some information later in the  presentation. So let's get started. So as you know, we have realigned the format of our update with the most recent guidance provided to us by the Virginia Department of Health. And as all public schools in Virginia are required to open five days a week for in-person instruction, the newly updated guidance provides five steps for school divisions to consider as operational decisions are made during the 21-22 school year. The first of these steps is to evaluate the level of community  disease transmission at the local level. So the level of community transmissions discernment is determined using two measures. The first is the total number of new cases per 100,000 people in the past seven days. And the most recent data we have is from Tuesday, September 21. And at that time, our seven day  total per 100,000 people was 276 cases, putting us in the high transmission category. The second measure is the percent of NAAT tests that are positive during the past seven days. And our latest percent positivity is 5.4%, which puts us in the moderate transmission category. And when those two indicators are at different levels, the VDH recommends using the indicator with the higher value. So our community transmission level at this time  is in the high category, as you can see the entire Commonwealth of Virginia. So the second step is to understand the community level of vaccination coverage. And as I've said before, this continues to be a bright spot in Albemarle County. In Albemarle, we have 86.3% of our 12 to 15 year olds vaccinated with one dose, and that's up from 84.3 the last time we spoke.  and we have 87.7% of our 16 and 17-year-olds with at least one dose of vaccine up from about 86.9. In terms of fully vaccinated students in those populations, our 12 to 15-year-olds have hit 77.9% up from 75.2, and our 16 and 17-year-old age group is at 80.9 up from 79.1%.  And the third step in our operational decision-making is to consider the level of impact that the virus is having within our schools. So now that students have returned to school, we can again use this metric as an operational strategy. And as expected, we continue to have positive cases in our schools, and the vast majority appear to be isolated cases. We are, however, tracking a small number of suspected connected cases where there are at least two or three cases in one class.  We'll continue to work with the Blue Ridge Health Department to determine if these are actual school to school transmissions. And so we are probably hovering between the low and the medium depending on the outcome of of those findings at the Blue Ridge Health Department.  One of the second criteria we have a student absenteeism, and we have started to put a little bit more of a metric around this, we are going to use our school year 1819 attendance rate as our baseline. That year, our division average and 95% attendance rate over the course of the year.  And since our last board meeting, our overall attendance rate in our schools was also at 95% for non-COVID absences. So our non-COVID absences are really staying about the same as our baseline is. When we look at today's COVID absences, we see that 2.7% of our students were working from home today due to COVID quarantine requirements. So our actual attendance rate was closer to 92% with that factored in.  So this would probably put us at the slightly above baseline or the medium level of impact for student absenteeism. And finally, we look at staff capacity. And as we speak to principals throughout the division, I really feel that we've got to classify our staff capacity as strained in the medium level here. We are seeing multiple schools in which teachers and administrative staff are having to cover classes for absent teachers because their positions were not picked up from a substitute.  That's a strain on a school. We'll continue to monitor all of these factors, both at the school and the division level, and we'll continue to make operational decisions on a school by school basis based on the level of impact at that particular school.  And as a final piece of our report, I'll remind the board of our layered approach to prevention strategies in our schools. We have and continue to have, we feel, strong mitigation strategies, which include promoting vaccination, consistent and correct use of masks, physical distancing, enhanced ventilation, a proper hand-washing and respiratory etiquette, cleaning and maintaining healthy facilities, having everyone stay home when they're sick and get tested, and contact tracing in combination  with isolation and quarantine.  In addition to our COVID metrics tonight, I'd like to provide you with some updated information about the status of our staff with regard to the COVID vaccine. As we shared at our last meeting, we've been collecting vaccine status information from our staff. This chart shows the updated information between our last meeting and now regarding all of our full and part-time regular employees. So as you can see, about 90% of all of our employees are fully vaccinated.  We've broken that out, broken that our teachers into a separate group. And here you can see that about 96 percent of our teachers are fully vaccinated. We know that these numbers will fluctuate as we gain and lose employees and as vaccination status changes for some employees.  When we take a deeper look into our teachers, you can see the breakdown between our instructional levels. We have about 95% of our elementary teachers, 97% of our middle school teachers fully vaccinated. This high rate of vaccination is especially helpful to know as most of our students at these levels are not yet able to receive the COVID vaccine themselves. And we've also begun collecting data on our temporary employees as well as our regular employees who have been hired.  And as you can see from this chart, our athletic coaches, short and long term substitutes, student teachers, new hires, and other temporary employees also have a high rate of COVID vaccination. And we'll continue to collect the information from this group as new folks come on to those positions.  And I'd also like to provide the board with a brief overview of the COVID testing program. As a reminder, any employee, regular or temporary, must participate in weekly COVID testing if they are not fully vaccinated. We began this testing last Wednesday and to date have received the results of 194 tests. We're awaiting results of 83 recent tests and have 28 employees who will need to test by tomorrow to be compliant with the testing regulation.  While Genetworks indicates a turnaround of testing results in 48 hours, at this point, we are seeing a better than average return of 18 hours for those tests. In this first round of testing, we've had two positive tests. And as a reminder, all of our employees may utilize our four testing sites regardless of their vaccination status. They can come get a test anytime they'd like.  And finally tonight, we are happy to say we've got Ryan McKay back with us from the Blue Ridge Health Department, and I was going to turn the floor over to Ryan, just to give you a brief update of what he's seeing, and we're also happy to take any questions from the board. So, Ryan.
speaker: patrickmclaughlin

text: Thank you for the opportunity to come and speak. My name is Ryan McKay I'm the director of policy planning and coven operations for Blue Ridge. So, as you know, and the community knows we've seen a pretty significant surge related to the delta variant, and just sort of going backwards a little bit. As we've mentioned in other forums.  Delta arrived here in Virginia and specifically the health district right around the same time that the executive orders expired so we've lost any of the mandates that were in place regarding social distancing masking limits to the number of individuals who could attend social gatherings or events.  And so that combination of the Delta variant and the opening up of our community and our society has really contributed both equally into where we stand at this point. We have seen a pretty significant surge, obviously with schools in place and children back on buses and in elementary, middle and high schools.  we are expecting to see cases emerge. I think that the benefit to having gone through this for the last year, year and a half, is that schools across the district and specifically with Albemarle County have done a tremendous job to mitigate the risk to the extent possible.  And I think important in that is that relying on the schools to do the contact tracing, once a case does emerge, and if that child has been in school whether infectious quickly identifying those individuals so that they can work on contact tracing. And that's one important change I think we want to highlight tonight.  So in the past we've been contacting families whose children are identified as close contacts. And what we recognize is that we're duplicating a lot of the effort that's already been put in place by school nurses and administrators who have already reached out to families.  And so what we're doing is we're going to continue to collect those line lists, rely on the contact that schools have made to those families, but we're not going to duplicate that effort anymore. And what this does is it allows us to focus on some of the community cases that we haven't gotten to in a timely fashion related to this particular search. And by doing so, we actually think we're going to minimize the number of children who may come to school because they would be put in quarantine prior to arrival.  So it's just an example of how much confidence we have in the school's ability to identify close contacts and then provide that information in a timely manner.  We continue to prepare for boosters. The FDA approved late last night boosters for certain groups. One which is kind of a broad category right now is 18 to 64 year olds who work in an institutional or occupational place that presents some sort of exposure risk. We don't have details on what that really means and we'll need to wait for Virginia Department of Health to approve all of that.  And obviously we're keeping a very close eye on what the FDA may do with Pfizer for 5 to 11 year olds. This is really the next big step in providing another layer of mitigation for schools for children who want to come to school and really minimizing the risk again to another extent possible using that.  No trends right now in terms of cases. We're seeing a little bit of a dip, but I don't want to say that we're on a downward trend with the current surge. So really critical that we continue to maintain all of the mitigation strategies that have been successfully implemented thus far. I'm happy to answer any questions you may have from the public health perspective.
speaker: ryanmckay

text: Well, I don't know if there's a test, but what I can say is that if an individual has tested positive for COVID,  they don't have to quarantine up to 90 days after that incident with COVID. Once 90 days is expired, we would have to put them into quarantine because there is the risk that they would get another infection. So vaccine is really what's going to be the long-term solution to preventing illness, serious health outcomes like hospitalizations or death.  So while it may be okay for a while post-COVID experience to have those antibodies, that wanes. And so really vaccination is the one thing that's going to last far beyond that 90-day period once someone has recovered from COVID.

text: So first part, availability of testing. It has increased a little bit. I think what's the challenge is depending on the situation. So symptomatic versus asymptomatic testing. Primary care providers, physicians' offices, family practices aren't going to test unless someone is symptomatic with COVID. And in a lot of cases, they'll require sort of an evaluation before then.  to make sure that the child is actually at risk based on potential exposure history. Asymptomatic testing is a little bit harder to come by. There are a few places that do offer it. We offer it at all of our testing sites, the ones that we run in Charlottesville and Albemarle, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday.  We do ask that people pre-register, which makes it a little more difficult. We've had open slots over the last few weeks. So individuals may see a long line, but it's not that we don't have tests. It's a little bit more about the time and the wait. So it is a little challenging, but we do offer a lot of free testing. And our UVA offers Monday and Tuesday.  And then occasionally, Dr. Vergolis from UVA has set up some sites with his team. I know Jack Jewett was used a couple of times in the last two weeks, and I believe tonight there's one at Charlottesville High School. So it's available. It is a challenge for individuals to find it. We're working on expanding ourselves to be able to provide more testing in the community.  and in more rural areas. So, for example, if we set up a site in Crozet-Afton area, that would hopefully serve the western part of the county and, in addition, some folks in Nelson County. So it's there. It's a little difficult to find, but particularly a few Monday nights in Nelson County, we just didn't have a ton of people.  It's a little bit of a drive, but it is available. I think weekends are also difficult to find testing, which has presented a challenge, certainly for students in Albemarle County when the testing on the eighth day was required. I think lifting that will provide some more opportunities for parents who need symptomatic testing to get tested. And then hopefully once we're back up and running with some more staff on our side, we'll be able to increase that access.  Second part. So pool testing in the VISTA program with VDH, I know they're promoting this extensively throughout Virginia, there's a lot of different avenues with it. One of the things that we've advised schools, and I believe Dr. Bonds has mentioned this in other meetings with Charlottesville City.  is that there is a resource requirement to it that I think is a little bit more of a heavy lift than what we would expect. There's planning involved, there's logistics, identifying a location within a school, coordinating with students and families to get consent forms. So while the program does offer some staffing support, there is a lift on the school end. And I think there's an operational decision that schools have to make and consider  when they're doing that. In particular, it's going to be potentially on the nurses, given that there's consent forms, there's a little bit of a medical component to it. And if your nurses are the ones that are also doing the case investigation and contact tracing within the schools, it's a decision about that level of burden. I think the other thing too is a lot of this is to prevent in-school transmission from occurring. And as we just heard from Dr. McLaughlin, in-school transmission isn't really occurring. I know you're keeping an eye on a couple of cases in one classroom,  But the preventative measures that you've already been using are really working and have been really successful. And I think even the numbers for in-school transmission last year, especially during the surge in February and March, were extremely low.  It is appropriate and we would recommend it when schools have had significant difficulty keeping transmission outside of school and unable to do it inside of school. There are some sort of smaller parts of that program that you may find to be more beneficial. Teams, for example, would be another area where that testing could take place. But again, I think it's looking at what's currently happening within the school.  Is in-school transmission occurring at a regular rate? And if so, and if you can't identify the reason why, that might be an opportunity to reconsider that. Schools in our district have been tremendously successful. They're gonna make decisions based on their need, obviously, but from what we're seeing with Albemarle County and a lot of the other schools, I'm not sure that it would add much benefit, given the percentage of students that you would be required to test, so about 20%, and in the number of cases you may find.  Again, those individuals who test positive as part of the pool process would still continue to go to school until the individual PCR test comes back. So it wouldn't necessarily reduce the number of students going into quarantine.  That's kind of our perspective and our thought on it. It really depends on the current situation within the schools. It really depends on what we're seeing in that in-school transmission and then the operational readiness of the school system to support it, even if most of the lift is done by the vendor.

And even if we were to add let's say another high school or various centers we likely wouldn't go below 1000 at any of our schools. The maximum had a lot of variability there really wasn't a lot of consensus within the Community about what would be a good maximum size.  The plurality of support was behind about 1,200 students, which is slightly in excess of where Monticello and Western Albemarle High School are right now, but could push up to about 1,400, which sits right around where our average is for all of our high schools. There doesn't seem to be a lot of support for that 1,800, but there was a considerable amount of support for around 2,000, which was an interesting data point  We don't have a lot of information about why people would think that a school that large that's so out of line with the rest of our state, as well as the market comparison that Maya showed us. We're not really sure why there's that support there. So after we completed this, we also did a review of some existing research on school sizes. If we click next, we reached out to EAB, and they did some research on ideal school size.  And so I'm going to shift hats a little bit to go from statistics to economics. Economics is not my background, so I apologize to anyone who's listening who knows this stuff way better than I do. I'm using some terms loosely, but the idea that we got was there's not a lot of consistency in the research. There is some, there's plenty of research out there about ideal school size, but there's no one definitive answer of where is that ideal. What they identify are two competing priorities. The first is the  The economies of scale right so as some resources are fungible you can increase the student enrollment without increasing that resource let's say a principal right, we can have a principal school of 100. We can also have a principal of school 300 so the cost for that principal doesn't change across the number of students enrolled. Except that the cost per pupil changes, so there creates an economy of scale.  What the research did identify was the law of diminishing returns, which is where when you reach a point that the economies of scale begin failing. And it's specific to students who need specialized support. And so that was, if you look in that very far right column, the special education and disadvantaged populations, this is where the economies of scale begin to falter. And so if we give an example like  Albemarle high school with roughly 2000 students enrolled and we have roughly 10% of our students identified as special education. That means there are potentially roughly 200 students who are in need of special education services at Albemarle high school. If we average roughly 10% 10 students on a caseload you're talking about 20 special education folks working at Albemarle high school in concert with one another.  If anyone sat in a room of 20 people and tried to find agreement, you'll understand the law of diminishing returns when it comes to some of these specialized populations. Similarly, when we look at our students that are from economically disadvantaged homes, they receive special economic support around things like Title I. So if we start to increase the number of Title I teachers in a school, so you start to have five, six, seven, eight Title I teachers,  it becomes very difficult for them to have productive PLC conversations. And so again, the law of diminishing returns becomes a problem. So there's not a right answer, but the idea is trying to maximize the economies of scale. But stopping before we hit that law of diminishing returns is what the research tells us is sort of the best idea. And I believe that's the end of my section.
